title: Stakeholder Engagement Planning
description: Learn to move stakeholders up the engagement continuum through tailored, proactive strategies.
objectives: Apply the Stakeholder Engagement Continuum: Unaware → Resistant → Neutral → Supportive → Leading
Prioritize stakeholders based on power level (high-power unaware stakeholders are most dangerous)
Select tailored engagement strategies based on stakeholder's current and desired engagement levels
Distinguish between Stakeholder Register (identification) and Stakeholder Engagement Plan (strategy)

screens.headline: 18 Stakeholders. 3 Critical Gaps. One Question: How Do You ENGAGE Them?

dialogue.text: Let's just send everyone the same project update email. That's efficient communication, right?

screens.learningHook: You've identified stakeholders and mapped their power/interest. But identification isn't enough. How do you ENGAGE them? High-power unaware stakeholders are the most dangerous—they can block the project when they become aware late.

screens.title: Match Engagement Strategies to Stakeholder Profiles
screens.instructions: For each stakeholder, identify the risk and select the optimal engagement strategy.

scenarios.title: Marcus Chen (CFO) - High Power, Unaware
description: Marcus is UNAWARE of the $2M expansion budget
Budget approval meeting is in 3 weeks
If Marcus learns about the project during approval (not before), he'll likely reject it

questions.question: What is the PRIMARY risk of having a high-power stakeholder who is UNAWARE?

options.text: Unaware stakeholders may not attend project meetings
High-power unaware stakeholders can block the project when they become aware at a late stage (most dangerous)
Unaware stakeholders may spread misinformation
Unaware stakeholders require more communication resources

feedback.correct: Exactly! High-power unaware stakeholders are MOST DANGEROUS because they can block the project when they become aware at critical decision points.
feedback.incorrect: The primary risk is that high-power unaware stakeholders can BLOCK the project when they finally become aware—usually at the worst possible time.

questions.question: What should Alex do to engage Marcus?

options.text: Wait until budget approval meeting to present project details
Schedule 1-on-1 meeting THIS WEEK: share project details, explain benefits, move him from Unaware → Supportive
Add Marcus to the project email distribution list
Ask the CEO to inform Marcus about the project

feedback.correct: Perfect! Proactive 1-on-1 engagement BEFORE the critical decision moves Marcus from Unaware → Supportive. Don't wait for surprises.
feedback.incorrect: Waiting or passive communication won't work. You need PROACTIVE engagement—meet with Marcus NOW, before the budget approval meeting.

scenarios.title: Jordan Kim (Operations Director) - High Power, Resistant
description: Jordan is RESISTANT to the 6-month timeline
Concerns: Staff training gaps, supply chain not ready
Has expressed strong opposition in 2 recent meetings

questions.question: What should Alex do when a high-power stakeholder is actively RESISTANT?

options.text: Ignore the resistance and proceed (they'll come around)
Compromise on project objectives to win support
Develop a tailored engagement plan: address Jordan's specific concerns, customize communication
Call a workshop with all 18 stakeholders to address concerns publicly

feedback.correct: Excellent! Tailored engagement addresses Jordan's SPECIFIC concerns (training, supply chain) without compromising project objectives.
feedback.incorrect: Don't ignore resistance (it escalates) or compromise objectives (undermines integrity). Develop a TAILORED plan for Jordan's specific concerns.

questions.question: Select Alex's best strategy for Jordan:

options.text: Proceed without addressing concerns
Weekly 1-on-1s, address training concerns, involve in supply chain planning, transparency on risks
Extend timeline to 9 months to win support
Escalate to CEO and ask her to override Jordan

feedback.correct: Perfect! Tailored engagement: regular touchpoints, address specific concerns, involve in solutions, build trust through transparency.
feedback.incorrect: The best approach is TAILORED engagement—address Jordan's specific concerns through 1-on-1s and involvement in planning.

scenarios.title: Community Board - Low Power, High Interest
description: Local community representatives concerned about traffic, noise, parking
No decision-making authority but high interest in project impact
Could mobilize community opposition if ignored

questions.question: According to the Power/Interest Grid, how should Alex engage LOW POWER + HIGH INTEREST stakeholders?

options.text: Manage Closely: frequent meetings, involve in all decisions
Keep Satisfied: minimal communication, meet their needs
Keep Informed: proactive regular communication, address concerns
Monitor: minimal effort, check occasionally

feedback.correct: Correct! Low Power + High Interest = KEEP INFORMED. Regular updates prevent them from mobilizing opposition.
feedback.incorrect: Low Power + High Interest stakeholders should be KEPT INFORMED. They can't make decisions but can create political pressure if ignored.

content.definition: Stakeholders exist on a 5-level engagement continuum. Your job: move them UP.

keyPoints.explanation: Doesn't know project exists. High-power unaware = MOST DANGEROUS
Knows project, actively opposes it. Needs tailored engagement
On the fence. Can go either way without proactive engagement
Actively champions project. Leverage their influence

content.insight: Movement is gradual. Resistant → Neutral → Supportive takes weeks of tailored engagement.

blocks.title: Prioritization Rule: High-Power Unaware is Most Dangerous

content.definition: Prioritize by POWER first, then engagement level.
priorityOrder: Priority 1: High-Power Unaware - Time bomb. Engage IMMEDIATELY.
Priority 2: High-Power Resistant - Very dangerous. Tailored engagement plan.
Priority 3: High-Power Neutral - Medium risk. Proactive engagement.
Priority 4: Low-Power Resistant - Don't ignore. Power can change.
content.insight: If Marcus (CFO, unaware) learns about $2M during approval meeting, he'll likely block it. Engage him 3 weeks early.

strategies.example: Marcus (CFO) - monthly updates focused on ROI
Community Board - monthly updates, open houses

principles.name: Early
principles.detail: Engage at project START, not when you need approval

principles.name: Frequent
principles.detail: Regular touchpoints based on power/interest level

principles.name: Transparent
principles.detail: Share good news AND bad news. Build trust.

content.insight: Late engagement = blindsided stakeholders = resistance. Early engagement = trust = support.

correct.text: I was unaware of the $2M budget. If Alex had waited until approval, I would have blocked it. But she met with me 3 weeks early—explained the ROI, addressed my concerns. By approval time, I was supportive.

incorrect.text: We waited until the approval meeting. Marcus rejected the budget on the spot—said he needed 2 weeks to review. Now we're delayed.

correct.text: I was resistant to the timeline. Alex didn't ignore me or compromise. She created a tailored plan: weekly 1-on-1s, involved me in training, showed transparency. Over 6 weeks, I moved from Resistant → Supportive.
Community Board has low power but high interest. Keep them informed—monthly updates prevent them from mobilizing opposition that creates political pressure on permits.

screens.title: Multi-Stakeholder Crisis Response
screens.context: Month 2 of expansion. Alex discovers THREE stakeholder issues simultaneously.

stakeholders.name: Taylor Singh
stakeholders.issue: Just learned about project, FURIOUS wasn't consulted on site selection

stakeholders.name: Sam Rodriguez
stakeholders.issue: Neutral but concerned about $2M budget risks

questions.question: Which stakeholder should Alex prioritize FIRST?

options.text: Taylor Singh (Real Estate Director)
Sam Rodriguez (Finance Manager)
Local Media

feedback.correct: Correct! Taylor is HIGH POWER + RESISTANT + late awareness = MOST URGENT. He can block project decisions.
feedback.incorrect: Taylor should be prioritized. High power + resistant + late awareness = most dangerous combination.

items.label: Taylor (High power, Resistant)
items.match: Tailored engagement: 1-on-1, acknowledge mistake, involve in solutions

items.label: Sam (Medium power, Neutral)
items.match: Proactive transparency: detailed budget, risk register, build trust

items.label: Media (Low power, Medium interest)
items.match: Keep Informed: press release, regular updates, don't over-engage

questions.question: What proactive engagement principle was violated that led to Taylor's resistance?

options.text: Should have compromised on project objectives
Should have engaged Taylor EARLY (during site selection)
Should have ignored Taylor (he's too difficult)
Should have escalated to leadership first

feedback.correct: Exactly! EARLY engagement was violated. Taylor should have been consulted during site selection, not after.
feedback.incorrect: The EARLY engagement principle was violated. Taylor should have been engaged during site selection.

screens.title: Stakeholder Engagement Mastery
screens.summary: You've learned to move stakeholders up the engagement continuum through tailored, proactive strategies.
takeaways: Engagement Continuum: Unaware → Resistant → Neutral → Supportive → Leading
Priority 1: High-power UNAWARE stakeholders are MOST DANGEROUS—engage immediately
Resistant stakeholders need TAILORED plans (don't ignore, don't compromise objectives)
Power/Interest Grid: Manage Closely, Keep Satisfied, Keep Informed, Monitor
Even 'leading' stakeholders must follow formal processes

artifacts.title: Stakeholder Engagement Quick Reference
artifacts.description: Continuum visual, prioritization rules, Power/Interest strategies

characterClosing.text: I wanted to send everyone the same email. Alex showed me: Marcus needs immediate engagement, Jordan needs a tailored plan, Community Board needs regular updates. Effective engagement is strategic and tailored.
